tossups.question: Fighters in this conflict forced sixteen employees of the American Smelting and Mining Company off a train for a summary execution. In response to increased U.S. involvement in this conflict, the ABC powers met at the Niagara Falls Conference. The U.S. prevented the SS Ypiranga (ee-pee-RAHN-gah) from sending weapons to this conflict after occupying a port in a dispute over nine detained American sailors and a 21-gun salute. The Tampico (tam-PEE-koh) affair occurred during this conflict, which included an operation that led George Patton to receive the nickname "Bandito." The burning of Columbus by a commander in this conflict led to the Punitive Expedition commanded by John Pershing. For 10 points, name this conflict that the US was drawn into during a raid by Pancho Villa.

The "re-entrant" keyhole motifs on these objects are variably interpreted as a fountain or as a gateway to heaven. The traditional use of these objects is inspired by an early leader's similar use of a palm-frond khumrah. Repeated contact with these objects or the similarly used earthen tablet called a turbah can result in a zabiba callus on the forehead. The Verse of Light is often symbolized by mosque lamps on these objects, "single niche" examples of which decorated Transylvanian churches until a ban on selling examples with depictions of the Kaaba or mihrab to non-Muslims. Users point the mihrab towards the qibla while performing rakat atop these objects, which includes steps of kneeling and prostration. For 10 points, many Muslims use what woven objects five times a day when praying upon them?

This symphony's scherzo, sometimes called a "Biedermeier minuet," was inspired by the love poem Lilis Park. The composer of this earliest "major/minor" symphony in the standard repertoire described it as "blue sky" in major key. Solo clarinet evokes a chanting priest in this symphony's D minor second movement, which is nicknamed for Ignaz Moscheles's claim that it took its melody from a Czech "Pilgrim's March." At the end of its finale, the composer combines previously stated saltarello and tarantella themes. This was the numerically latter of two symphonies written after a "Grand Tour" that also inspired the Hebrides Overture and the composer's third symphony. For 10 points, name this numerical successor to the "Scottish" symphony, inspired by travels in Naples and Rome taken by the German composer of the "Reformation" symphony.
tossups.formatted_answer: "Italian" symphony [or Felix Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 4 in A major; or Mendelssohn's fourth]
tossups.answer: "Italian" symphony [or Felix Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 4 in A major; or Mendelssohn's fourth]

tossups.question: This author wrote of the departure of "saints-to-be" and "intendant Caesars" in a poem that describes "the poet, admired for his earnest habit of calling the sun the sun," whose "antimythological myth" is doubted by "marble statues." This poet described trying to imagine "a faultless love or the life to come," then hearing "underground streams" and seeing a landscape "we, the inconstant ones, are consistently homesick for." Larry Kramer's The Normal Heart takes its title from a poem by this author that recounts "what mad Nijinsky wrote about Diaghilev." This author described "children afraid of the night who have never been happy or good" in a poem whose speaker says, "We must love one another or die," while in "one of the dives on Fifty-Second Street." For 10 points, name this poet of "In Praise of Limestone" and "September 1, 1939."

The Jacobian used to process data obtained from this phenomenon, which incorporates its "shear" gamma and "convergence" kappa, is subject to mass-sheet degeneracy. In 1998, the MERLIN network first observed an effect of this phenomenon sometimes named for its early theorist Orest Khvolson. The motion of this phenomenon's source can cause variation called "xallarap" (ZAHL-uh-rap). An object discovered by John Huchra (HOOK-rah) causes this phenomenon to produce a "cross" pattern. This phenomenon has the characteristic angle "4 G M over r c squared." This phenomenon was first observed in the Twin Quasar 55 years after it was predicted using general relativity. When the source and observer are perfectly aligned, this phenomenon produces circular patterns called Einstein rings. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in which stars and galaxies bend light around them.
tossups.formatted_answer: gravitational lensing [or gravitational microlensing or weak gravitational lensing or strong gravitational lensing; prompt on lensing]
tossups.answer: gravitational lensing [or gravitational microlensing or weak gravitational lensing or strong gravitational lensing; prompt on lensing]

tossups.question: This character is the alphabetically latter who titles a paper that Quine cites as opposing conventionalism in "Truth by Convention." This character puns on the fact that his interlocutor "taught" after months at a riverbank going through a regress argument that begins with denoting the statement "A and B implies Z" as C; the argument stems from the other speaker saying "solvitur ambulando." In reference to that paper by Lewis Carroll, this non-human character dialogues in sections named for the Two and Three Part Inventions in Douglas Hofstadter's Godel, Escher, Bach. With modern knowledge of convergent series, one may show it takes roughly 10.1 seconds for this character to be overtaken in a story that Aristotle equated with the creator's dichotomy paradox. For 10 points, name this animal who races Achilles in one of Zeno's paradoxes.

A character in this story asks, "Does the trees moving make the wind blow?" and "Why are oranges round?" The narrator of this story lies about having shoulder pain after a threat of being burned at the stake. After falling on a frying pan, a character in this story says that King Herod is his favorite Biblical figure. A character in this story laments that sand "ain't a palpable substitute" for oats. The narrator of this story hides in a tree for four and a half hours to make sure that no constable follows him. A character in this story is nicknamed "Old Hank" and is forced to act like a horse. In this story, which takes place near the town of Summit, the narrator and Bill Driscoll pay $250 to return the obnoxious son of Ebenezer Dorset. For 10 points, name this story about the failed kidnapping of a young boy, by O. Henry.

During an incident in Kyoto, this man was guided through Iga (ee-gah) province to a shore in order to travel by sea to Mikawa province. After accusations of his family collaborating with Takeda Katsuyori (tah-kay-dah kat-soo-yor-ee), this man had his wife Lady Tsukiyama executed and his son forced to commit seppuku. This man left his five provinces to rule over the Kanto region alongside the Hojo clan, leading to a proverb about how this man "won the empire by retreating." This man held the most koku of the Council of Five Elders, a group that held the regency after Toyotomi Hideyoshi's death. The defeat of Ishida Mitsunari's army at the Battle of Sekigahara (sek-ee-gah-hah-rah) allowed this warlord's clan to unify Japan under his leadership from his castle in Edo. For 10 points, name this lord who established Japan's final shogunate (show-gun-ate), lasting from 1603 to 1868.

When taken in later pregnancy, these drugs increase the risk of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn. The first level of the STAR*D trial tested these drugs. S·L·C·6·A·4 variants can blunt the effects of these drugs. Abrupt discontinuation of these drugs can cause shock-like experiences called zaps. These medications are first-line for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder. These drugs have largely replaced tricyclics and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. Because of the "energizing phenomenon", these drugs may temporarily increase suicidal ideation in the first two months. Common examples of these drugs include escitalopram and fluoxetine, or Lexapro and Prozac. For 10 points, name these antidepressants that restrict the transmission of a certain mood-related neurotransmitter.
tossups.formatted_answer: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [or SSRIs; prompt on antidepressants until mentioned; anti-prompt on specific SSRIs such as escitalopram, fluoxetine, Lexapro, or Prozac until mentioned]
tossups.answer: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [or SSRIs; prompt on antidepressants until mentioned; anti-prompt on specific SSRIs such as escitalopram, fluoxetine, Lexapro, or Prozac until mentioned]

tossups.question: Mesopotamia scholar Samuel Noah Kramer posited that this event in Greek myth was derived from a Sumerian myth involving Ereshkigal and Kur. After this event, Cyane was either turned to liquid or dissolved away in tears. The swineherd Eubuleus was feeding his pigs near where this event occurred, and thus lost his pigs during it. Ovid wrote that the Sirens were given wings in response to this event, while Hyginus wrote they were cursed for failing to prevent it. The Homeric hymn recounting this event gives the Plain of Nysa as where it took place. A goddess wandered for nine days with Hectate's torches after this event, causing nothing to grow on Earth. For 10 points, give this event where a daughter of Demeter was taken to the underworld.
tossups.formatted_answer: Hades' abduction of Persephone [accept any answers describing the taking of Persephone by Hades, prompt on answers like abduction or kidnapping that don't mention Persephone]
tossups.answer: Hades' abduction of Persephone [accept any answers describing the taking of Persephone by Hades, prompt on answers like abduction or kidnapping that don't mention Persephone]

tossups.question: This story's author refers to H.G. Wells's dictum about only allowing "one fantastic element... at a time" in a commentary on a translation produced with Norman Thomas di Giovanni. A four-line stanza that alludes to the Odyssey, Works and Days, and an "immortal bagatelle" by Xavier de Maistre exemplifies the pompous erudition of a poet in this story. This story closes by telling of a pillar in Cairo's mosque of Amr (AH-mir) in which a "busy hum" can be heard. This story's narrator notes that his book The Sharper's Card is less successful than his friend's poem The Earth. That narrator goes to the house of the deceased Beatriz Viterbo and looks at the nineteenth step in the cellar to find the "small iridescent sphere" that titles this story. For 10 points, "a point in space that contains all other points" titles what story by Jorge Luis Borges?

Before Oliver Stone's Platoon, this director used Barber's Adagio for Strings as a John Hurt character dies in his sleep, after which Tennyson's "Nothing Will Die" is recited. In another film by this director, Cherubini's C minor Requiem plays as Leland kills his daughter in a train car, before wrapping her in plastic and throwing her in a river. In a series by this director with a theme by Angelo Badalamenti, a depiction of the Trinity test is accompanied by Penderecki's Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima. Isabella Rossellini performs the title song of a film by this director as nightclub singer Dorothy Vallens, who is tormented by the gas-huffing Frank Booth. This director depicted the murder of Laura Palmer in a film subtitled "Fire Walk with Me." For 10 points, name this director of The Elephant Man, Blue Velvet, and Twin Peaks.
tossups.formatted_answer: David Lynch [David Keith Lynch] [Clues are from The Elephant Man, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me, Twin Peaks: The Return, Blue Velvet, and Twin Peaks, in that order.]
tossups.answer: David Lynch [David Keith Lynch] [Clues are from The Elephant Man, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me, Twin Peaks: The Return, Blue Velvet, and Twin Peaks, in that order.]

tossups.question: Australia's Tom Malone Prize is awarded each year to the best artwork in this medium. University of Wisconsin professor Harvey K. Littleton helped found a movement for studio-made works in this medium along with researcher Dominick Labino at the Toledo Museum of Art. An artist worked with Lino Tagliapietra to create an Art Deco series in this medium titled Venetian. Murrine patterns can appear on artworks in this medium created via millefiori or caneworking. Many works in this medium are made at a Seattle Center studio by the eyepatch-wearing Dale Chihuly. Clara Driscoll led the "girls" who designed works in a type of this medium called Favrile for Louis Comfort Tiffany. For 10 points, name this medium whose "stained" variety was frequently used in medieval churches for rose windows.
tossups.formatted_answer: glass [accept stained glass; or Tiffany glass; or blown glass; accept glass vases]
tossups.answer: glass [accept stained glass; or Tiffany glass; or blown glass; accept glass vases]

tossups.question: Bishops of this city presided over each of the three Councils of Ephesus (EFF-uh-sis). A theologian from this city was condemned, in part, for teaching apocatastasis (AP-oh-kuh-TAS-tuh-sis) and compiled the Hexapla. At the First Council of Nicaea (nai-SEE-uh), Arius was opposed by a young deacon from this city named Athanasius. By hiding a body with pork, two Venetian merchants worked with monks to smuggle Saint Mark's relics out of this city. A Christian mob in this home city of Origen (OR-ih-jen) made a "martyr for philosophy" by killing the Neoplatonist Hypatia. This city is the southernmost whose Patriarch was in the Pentarchy, with the bishops of Rome, Constantinople, Jerusalem and Antioch. The Coptic Pope, who resides elsewhere in the national capital, is officially the bishop of this city. For 10 points, what city's Christian population destroyed the Serapion (ser-AP-ee-on) that succeeded its Great Library?

This compound's ability to activate the R·y·R's induces calcium sensitivity in high concentrations. A mixture of sodium nitrite, acetic acid, sodium carbonate, and chloroform is used to remove the blue glow of this compound following its synthesis. When administered in solution with citrate, this compound can treat lumbar-puncture-induced headaches, and its ability to non-specifically inhibit P·D·Es makes it a weak bronchodilator. A methyl group is removed from this compound's xanthine base to yield its three most common metabolites, which include theophylline and theobromine. Carbon dioxide's use as a green solvent first gained popularity from supercritical extractions of this alkaloid. This is the most common drug antagonist of adenosine receptors. For 10 points, name this addictive stimulant found in coffee.

Two married researchers with this surname lend their name to the flanker task used to study conflicting stimuli. A Yale professor of this surname studied Appalachia's susceptibility to "disaster syndrome" in the book Everything in Its Path. In her 90s, an ethnographer with this surname conceptualized a "Woven Cycle of Life" to replace a despair-centered paradigm. James Marcia proposed "moratorium" and "achievement" statuses building off of a thinker with this surname who had considered fidelity a sign of overcoming "role confusion." Per that psychologist of this surname, fidelity is among the virtues formed through overcoming dichotomies such as trust-mistrust and competence-inferiority. For 10 points, give this surname of a couple who pioneered an eight-stage model of psychosocial development, one of whom coined "identity crisis."
tossups.formatted_answer: Erikson [accept Erik Homburger Erikson or Joan Mowat Erikson; accept Erik Salomonsen or Sarah Lucretia Serson; accept Kai Erikson; accept Eriksen flanker task; accept Barbara Eriksen or Charles Eriksen]
tossups.answer: Erikson [accept Erik Homburger Erikson or Joan Mowat Erikson; accept Erik Salomonsen or Sarah Lucretia Serson; accept Kai Erikson; accept Eriksen flanker task; accept Barbara Eriksen or Charles Eriksen]

tossups.question: A monologue in this play describes "all men and beasts," "silent fish that inhabit the waves," and "starfish from the sea" that have died out at last. In the first act of this play, a character complains that a chained dog's constant barking is keeping his sister awake. A woman in this play bursts into tears after another man refuses her a carriage because he is using the horses to farm. In this play's first act, a mother mocks her son's use of sulfur to represent Satan during a performance. A medallion from Days and Nights stating that "If you ever need my life, take it" is given to a novelist in this play, which ends with a character shooting himself after reuniting with the actress Nina. For 10 points, name this Anton Chekhov play in which Konstantin Treplev's suicide mirrors the death of the title bird.

A configuration named for this scientist, in which three collinear masses orbit their center of mass, is an unstable solution to the three-body problem. Some equations named for this scientist, which give rise to the polhode (POLL-hode) curve when visualized using Poinsot's (pwan-SOZE) construction, feature terms like "I sub three minus I sub two, all times omega two omega three." The rate of change of angular velocity crossed with position gives this scientist's namesake acceleration. This scientist's namesake equations describe the rotation of a rigid body, which can be conveniently described using this scientist's namesake angles. This scientist co-names the equations of the calculus of variations with Joseph-Louis Lagrange (luh-GRANZH). For 10 points, name this scientist whose ubiquitous namesake constant equals about 2.718 and is denoted "e."
tossups.formatted_answer: Leonhard Euler (OIL-er) [or Euler's equations or Euler acceleration or Euler force or Euler angles or Euler-Lagrange equations or Euler's number]
tossups.answer: Leonhard Euler (OIL-er) [or Euler's equations or Euler acceleration or Euler force or Euler angles or Euler-Lagrange equations or Euler's number]

tossups.question: The Lámh Lachtaín (lawv LOCK-tawn) is one of only two surviving containers for these objects designed to look like an arm. House-shaped containers for these objects were popular in 8th-century Ireland and may have influenced the design of decorated chassis built to hold these non-book objects. The Duc de Berry commissioned a golden stand in which 28 enamel figures surround one of these objects. A silver band supposedly forged from one of these objects is found at the center of the Iron Crown, which was used to crown Charlemagne as King of Lombardy. Erasmus quipped about the supposed quantity of these objects, which were counterfeited by the hundreds for sale to pilgrims at sites such as the Shrine of Thomas Becket. For 10 points, name these sacred objects that were once possessions or body parts of a saint.
tossups.formatted_answer: relics [or relics of saints; or relics of Jesus; prompt on bone; prompt on thorns; prompt on nails; prompt on fragments of the True Cross]
tossups.answer: relics [or relics of saints; or relics of Jesus; prompt on bone; prompt on thorns; prompt on nails; prompt on fragments of the True Cross]

tossups.question: The missionary John Batchelor documented this people's language. This people built modified dugout canoes called "ita-oma-cip" to travel overseas. Necklaces worn by these people called tamasay (tuh-MASS-ee) may be embellished with a medallion representing the white-tailed eagle. Willow or alder wood is used for ritual prayer sticks among these people called inau (eh-naw). Epics of these people are collected in "yukar." Men of this ethnic group wear crowns called sapanpe (saw-PAN-pay) during festivals like the iomante (eye-oh-MAN-tay). These people believe in supernatural spirits called kamuy (ka-MOO-ee). These people drink the blood of and then "send off" brown bears. This ethnic group's tradition of long, unshaven male beards caused tension during attempted assimilation with Yamato settlers. For 10 points, name this indigenous ethnic group of the island of Hokkaido in northern Japan.

Leonard Bernstein, Yehudi Menuhin and Vladimir Horowitz all performed part of this piece at the conclusion of Carnegie Hall's 1976 "Concert of the Century." At this piece's premiere, a clergyman supposedly declared "for this be all thy sins forgiven thee!" to a performer who was embroiled in a divorce suit, namely Susanna Cibber ("kibber"). Ebenezer Prout restored the high trumpet parts to this piece that were removed in Mozart's German-language version. In Victorian performances, 4,000-strong groups would perform "big" versions of this piece, using words written by Charles Jennens in parts such as "The trumpet shall sound" and "I know that my Redeemer liveth." Legendarily, King George II stood up during a part of this piece that repeats "He shall reign forever and ever." For 10 points, what Handel oratorio includes the Hallelujah chorus?
tossups.formatted_answer: Messiah [antiprompt on Hallelujah chorus] [Bernstein, Menuhin and Horowitz were all part of the chorus.]
tossups.answer: Messiah [antiprompt on Hallelujah chorus] [Bernstein, Menuhin and Horowitz were all part of the chorus.]

bonuses.leadin: This text contains a set of nine practical principles such as "Become acquainted with every art," which are supplemented by the twenty-one "spirtual principles" of the author's Dokkodo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this treatise made up of Books of Earth, Water, Fire, Wind, and Void. Like the Hagakure, this Miyamoto Musashi book is a major source on Edo period bushido.
Musashi's Book of Void draws on the philosophy of this Mahayana tradition analyzed in "the Art of Archery" by Eugen Herrigel. Its Soto, Rinzai, and Obaku schools study paradoxical koan.

A thinker with this surname wrote "Zen and the Samurai" in Zen and Japanese Culture, and penned a 1934 Introduction to Zen Buddhism. Nurtured by Love contains the philosophy of a musical pedagogue of this surname.
answers: The Book of Five Rings [or Go Rin no Sho]
Zen Buddhism [accept Chan Buddhism; prompt on Mahayana; prompt on Buddhism]
formatted_answers: The Book of Five Rings [or Go Rin no Sho]
Zen Buddhism [accept Chan Buddhism; prompt on Mahayana; prompt on Buddhism]

bonuses.leadin: In a debate between these two men, one of them partly relied on Adriaan van Maanen's (MAR-nenz) observations of the Pinwheel Galaxy's rotation, which turned out to be wrong. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these two astronomers, whose much-publicised 1920 "Great Debate" centered on whether other galaxies were "island universes" or not.
Shapley essentially argued that all other observed galaxies, including Andromeda, were actually smaller parts of this galaxy, in which the Solar System is located.

Curtis meanwhile argued that Andromeda was a separate galaxy, though at the time he referred to it as a "spiral" one of these astronomical objects. The first entry in the Messier catalog is an iconic one of these astronomical objects.
answers: Harlow Shapley and Heber Curtis [both answers required; accept answers in either order]
formatted_answers: Harlow Shapley and Heber Curtis [both answers required; accept answers in either order]

bonuses.leadin: This economist and his alphabetically later co-worker gave bags of grain to mothers in Rajasthan to encourage them to have their children vaccinated. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this co-winner of the 2019 Economics Nobel, who developed a "radical rethinking of the way to fight global poverty" with his wife in the book Poor Economics.

Banerjee and Duflo frequently make use of controlled trials in which subjects are assigned in this manner. Before computer technology, dice throws and roulette wheels could be used to select members of a sample in this manner.
This earlier Indian economist stated that impoverished people are more at-risk during famines due to inequalities in food distribution mechanisms in the book Poverty and Famines.
answers: randomization [or word forms; or obvious equivalents such as by chance; accept randomized controlled trial; accept random sample]
formatted_answers: randomization [or word forms; or obvious equivalents such as by chance; accept randomized controlled trial; accept random sample]

bonuses.leadin: Following this event, London resident A. H. Burgess proposed donating books for a public library whose main branch is now named for Harold Washington. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event that started on DeKoven Street and destroyed the original Palmer House, but not Mahlon Ogden's residence, St. Michael's Church, or a historic water tower.
After the Great Chicago Fire, the mayor declared this type of law to prevent looting and riots. In addition to times of disorder, this type of law is often instituted in occupied territories.

This former Civil War general enforced martial law following the Great Chicago Fire. This short man promoted use of the military to protect Yellowstone and defeated Jubal Early at the Battle of Cedar Creek.
answers: Great Chicago Fire [or Great Fire of Chicago; prompt on partial answers]
formatted_answers: Great Chicago Fire [or Great Fire of Chicago; prompt on partial answers]

bonuses.leadin: In its home country, this city names the Gallipolli Campaign and contains a stool-like memorial for the defenders. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this nearest major city to the ancient sites of Abydos and Troy. A bridge named for this city, which opened in March 2022, is now the longest suspension bridge in the world.
Çanakkale is near the narrowest part of the Dardanelles, a strait in this country. The Bosporus forms part of the boundary between this country's European and Asian parts.
This sea lies between the Bosporus and the Dardanelles. The cities of Erdek and Izmit name two gulfs on this Turkish inland sea which borders Istanbul opposite the Black Sea.

bonuses.leadin: A novel set in this country was inspired by an earlier author's quote, "I believe that humans should be plants." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, the setting of a novel in which a woman escapes a mental hospital to stand in the rain like a tree and tries to kill herself when force-fed pork.
Han Kang cited an author who wrote under this surname as an influence on The Vegetarian. That author of "The Wings" and Crow's Eye View shares this surname with the author of The Heartless.

The English translation of The Vegetarian won the Yi Sang Prize and this literary prize. In 2022, Bora Chung's Cursed Bunny was shortlisted for this International version of a prize originally reserved for British Isles, South African, and Commonwealth authors.
answers: South Korea [or Republic of Korea; or Hanguk; or Namhan; or Daehan Minguk; prompt on Korea]
Yi [or Lee; or I; accept Yi Sang or Yi Kwang-su or Yi Sun-shin; prompt on Kim with "Please give the surname of the author's pen name"]
formatted_answers: South Korea [or Republic of Korea; or Hanguk; or Namhan; or Daehan Minguk; prompt on Korea]
Yi [or Lee; or I; accept Yi Sang or Yi Kwang-su or Yi Sun-shin; prompt on Kim with "Please give the surname of the author's pen name"]

bonuses.leadin: This man commissioned the painting The Beguiling of Merlin by Edward Burne-Jones, who also created an Arts and Crafts funerary monument for this man. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this art patron of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood. This man is depicted as a monstrous creature playing the piano atop a white house in the painting The Gold Scab.

Leyland commissioned Thomas Jekyll to plan this large artwork as his dining room. Now in the Freer Gallery of Art, this artwork contains the painting The Princess from the Land of Porcelain and is named for a bird.
Leyland frequently patronized this artist of The Gold Scab and muralist for The Peacock Room. This artist's painting Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1 depicts his mother.
answers: Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room [or Harmony in Blue and Gold]
formatted_answers: Harmony in Blue and Gold: The Peacock Room [or Harmony in Blue and Gold]

bonuses.leadin: The photo "Aid from the Padre" was taken during a June 1962 attempt to overthrow this party's founder, Rómulo Betancourt (roh-MOO-loh bet-ahn-KOR). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Venezuelan political party opposed by the Rafael Caldera-led COPEI (koh-PAY). By signing the Punto Fijo (POON-toh FEE-hoh) Pact at Caldera's residence, this party gained its dominant role in the country's two-party system from 1958 to 1998.

As the main opposition under the Punto Fijo system, Caldera's COPEI party followed this ideology synthesizing politics with "popular Catholic action." Major center-right parties in Italy and Germany were named for this ideology in the 20th century.
The Punto Fijo system ended in 1999 when Hugo Chavez took office and imposed a new political system as part of what Chavez labeled a revolution named for this 19th century "liberator."
answers: Christian Democracy [or Demócrata Cristiano; or word forms such as Christian Democrats; or Social Christian Party; or Partido Socialcristiano]
formatted_answers: Christian Democracy [or Demócrata Cristiano; or word forms such as Christian Democrats; or Social Christian Party; or Partido Socialcristiano]

bonuses.leadin: An equation describing these devices includes a term that sums the product of the selectivity coefficient and the activity raised to the power of the ionic valencies. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these devices, which can be calibrated using a Gran plot. Interference in these devices can be calculated with the Nikolsky-Shultz-Eisenman equation.
Glass electrodes are most often used to measure this quantity. If a solution has a value lower than 7 for this quantity, it is considered acidic.
Some glass electrodes use glass formed from these elements, which can respond to double-charged ions. Those glasses can contain telluride and selenide, ions of elements in this group.
answers: glass electrodes [accept but do not reveal pH electrodes; prompt on electrodes or ion-selective electrodes or pH meder]
formatted_answers: glass electrodes [accept but do not reveal pH electrodes; prompt on electrodes or ion-selective electrodes or pH meder]

bonuses.leadin: The first production of Athol Fugard's Serpent Players was an adaptation of this play entitled The Cure. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play, whose prologue wishes that "all of you might be tricked as" the "wise young woman" Lucrezia, whom Callimaco gives the title drug while disguised as a doctor.
This author of The Mandrake lends his name to a stock character of English Renaissance drama whose ruthless scheming is reminiscent of the advice given in his treatise The Prince.

The ghost of Machiavel opens this Elizabethan play, whose Machiavellian title character drinks "of poppy and cold mandrake juice" to fake his own death after poisoning a convent of nuns, including Abigail.
answers: Niccolò Machiavelli [Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli; or Nicholas Machiavel]
The Jew of Malta [or The Famous Tragedy of the Rich Jew of Malta] (by Christopher Marlowe)
formatted_answers: Niccolò Machiavelli [Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli; or Nicholas Machiavel]
The Jew of Malta [or The Famous Tragedy of the Rich Jew of Malta] (by Christopher Marlowe)

bonuses.leadin: While visiting a venue in this country, a composer was surprised by a sign that read "please don't throw lighted cigarette butts on the floor, so the ladies don't burn their feet." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country. That American composer wrote a 1936 piece inspired by a dance hall in this country after they were taken to it by the composer of Sinfonía ("sin-fo-NEE-ah") india.
This composer co-opted Mexican folk tunes for their piece El Salón México ("sah-LON MAY-hi-co"). He also quoted American folk music in the ballet Rodeo.

A Cuban orchestra who regularly performed at the original Salón México composed a piece named for it which exemplified this official musical genre of Cuba. Mexican composer Arturo Márquez is best-known for his second piece in this genre.

bonuses.leadin: The effect that underlies these devices was discovered by Edmond Becquerel, the father of radioactivity co-discoverer Henri Becquerel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these devices, whose first solid-state type was built by Charles Fritts in 1883. These devices are often placed on roofs in order to convert sunlight into electricity.

Fritts produced his original solar cell by coating this element with gold. Willoughby Smith had discovered that this element becomes more conductive the more light is shone on it, a fact which also underpinned Alexander Graham Bell's photophone.
In order to ensure scientific priority for his discovery, Fritts sent some of his cells to this engineer and industrialist. An SI unit named for this scientist is equal to the inverse ohm.
answers: solar cells [or photovoltaic cells or solar panels or PVs or photovoltaic effect]
formatted_answers: solar cells [or photovoltaic cells or solar panels or PVs or photovoltaic effect]

bonuses.leadin: Istanbul's Pudding Shop was a common stop for travelers from this movement, who were known to take the Magic Bus starting from Amsterdam. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this movement whose namesake "trail" involved hitchhiking from Western Europe through Turkey, Iran, and Afghanistan, ultimately reaching India or Kathmandu.
Travelers from the hippie movement were an example of this unconventional artistic lifestyle, often characterized by impoverished living. It takes its name from a historical Czech region.

The hippie movement also has roots in the Wandervogel (VAHN-dair-voh-gul), an early German movement centered around these organizations. Dutch hippies called Provos used smoke bombs to protest Queen Beatrix's husband being involved with a far-right example of these organizations.

bonuses.leadin: This was the first married surname of a poet who mourns men dying "in that holocaust of hell" while only able to "sit and sew." For 10 points each:
parts: Give this surname of a poet with first name Alice, who later added the surname Nelson. Her first husband with this surname wrote of wearing an object that "grins and lies...hides our cheeks and shades our eyes."

In "We Wear the Mask," Dunbar laments that we perform this action, "but oh, the clay is vile, beneath our feet, and long the mile." The speaker tells Miss Lucy to "quit" doing this in a Dunbar poem about Malindy performing this action.
Alice Dunbar Nelson wrote that the iron grates of the Library of Congress's book stacks inspired Dunbar's "Sympathy," whose speaker claims to know why a creature inside one of these objects sings.

bonuses.leadin: With the possible exclusion of the Berlin pedestal relief found in this modern country, a stele that Flinders Petrie found here contains the oldest known extra-Biblical reference to Israel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, whose ancient kingdom's chariots have been the subject of underwater searches inspired by the Song of Moses.

If Andre Lemaire's reconstructed text is correct, a stele named for this kingdom's ruler Mesha contains an earlier mention of the "House of David" than the Tel Dan stele. Balak and Eglon are other Biblical rulers of this homeland of Ruth.

Those steles join Egypt's Merneptah stele and this civilization's Kurkh Monoliths as the only known contemporary artifacts that mention Israel. Nahum preached its downfall, and Jonah visited its capital.
answers: Kingdom of Moab [or word forms such as Moabites]
Assyria [or word forms such as Assyrians; accept Neo-Assyrian Empire]
formatted_answers: Kingdom of Moab [or word forms such as Moabites]
Assyria [or word forms such as Assyrians; accept Neo-Assyrian Empire]

bonuses.leadin: The political party Telem (TELL-em) was founded in 1981 by this man, who was fighting Axis-affiliated forces in Syria when a sniper shot his binoculars in 1941. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this eyepatch-wearing Israeli who was Chief of Staff of the IDF during the Suez Crisis and Minister of Defense during the Six-Day War.

After being injured in 2001 during the Sri Lankan Civil War, this war correspondent began wearing an eyepatch. This woman was killed by the Syrian military while covering the siege of Homs (hahmz) in 2012.
Congressman Dan Crenshaw began wearing an eyepatch after being wounded by an IED blast while fighting a war in this country against the Taliban.
answers: Afghanistan [or Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan; or Də Afġānistān Islāmī Imārat; or Imārat-i Islāmī-yi Afghānistān]
formatted_answers: Afghanistan [or Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan; or Də Afġānistān Islāmī Imārat; or Imārat-i Islāmī-yi Afghānistān]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about music based on decaying recordings, for 10 points each.
parts: A 2020 TikTok challenge sparked a resurgence in music by the Caretaker that illustrates dementia through decaying recordings of a dance music genre named for these places. Foxtrots and waltzes are performed at dance competitions named for these large rooms.

A Gavin Bryars piece includes decaying and reverberating repetitions of the hymn tune "Autumn" in reference to the legendary performance of either that song or "Nearer, My God, to Thee" during this event. It also inspired a Meredith Willson musical partly titled for Molly Brown.
William Basinski used decaying tape recordings of his old music to create this avant-garde four-part album series.
answers: ballrooms [or ballroom dancing; or Selected Memories from the Haunted Ballroom]
the sinking of the RMS Titanic [or The Sinking of the Titanic; or descriptions indicating the Titanic disaster]
formatted_answers: ballrooms [or ballroom dancing; or Selected Memories from the Haunted Ballroom]
the sinking of the RMS Titanic [or The Sinking of the Titanic; or descriptions indicating the Titanic disaster]

bonuses.leadin: An author with this surname wrote of Kate Brady and Baba Brennan in her censored debut novel The Country Girls. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this surname of Irish novelist Edna. Another writer used this surname to publish a metafictional book in which Finn Mac Cool, Mad King Sweeney, and Pooka McPhillimey rebel against their author.

In Flann O'Brien's novel The Dalkey Archive, this author fakes his death and works as a bartender. Edna O'Brien began writing after she learned that this author's A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man was autobiographical.

In addition to At Swim-Two-Birds, Flann O'Brien also wrote this novel, in which a scholar of de Selby murders Mathers to get the money to publish his work. This novel ends with Pluck asking, "Is it about a bicycle?"

bonuses.leadin: Oshun transforms into a peacock to fly to this deity and ask him to end a drought, but as her feathers fall off and are scorched by the sun, she becomes a vulture. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this creator deity, who sent about four hundred lesser spirits to Earth to act as intermediaries. Obatala creates human bodies, but they are not alive until this god breathes "emi" into them.
E. Bolaji Idowu's book Olodumare is subtitled for God in the belief of this West African ethnic group, whose worship of orishas spread through such diasporic religions as Santeria and Candomble.
The Aja, Ewe, and Fon practice a traditional religion of this name. Yoruba-influenced syncretic Cuban, Dominican, Louisianan, and Haitan religions of this name venerate loa.
answers: Voodoo [or Vodon; or Vodoun; or Vodou; or any other variant spelling or pronunciation]
formatted_answers: Voodoo [or Vodon; or Vodoun; or Vodou; or any other variant spelling or pronunciation]

bonuses.leadin: During a physical examination, pressing on the right upper quadrant is a way to rule out this organ being affected by cholecystitis ("kow-luh-si-STAI-tuhs"). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organ, which contracts in response to C·C·K. This organ can take on a porcelain appearance when it calcifies.

The bile stored in the gallbladder contains bilirubin, which is a degradation product of this protein's prosthetic group. This iron-containing protein with four subunits carries oxygen in the bloodstream.

There exists a sonographic version of this medical sign, in which the patient is asked to breathe in while the examiner presses on the gallbladder. If the patient feels pain, then this medical sign is positive and cholecystitis is likely.

bonuses.leadin: Members of this university's "Riot Club" smash up a country pub and assault a prostitute in Laura Wade's play Posh. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British university attended by Charles Ryder in Brideshead Revisited. William Shakespeare is the most cited individual author in this university's English Dictionary.

A. E. Housman reminisces about his time with Moses Jackson at Oxford in this author's play The Invention of Love. This author also included a historical author in his play Travesties, which depicts Henry Carr's meeting with Tristan Tzara.

Hector, Irwin and Lintott prepare students at Cutlers' Grammar School for their Oxford interviews in this 2004 play, in which David remarks that he has no chance because "I'm a Jew. I'm small. I'm a homosexual. And I live in Sheffield."
